description.narrative: The programme aims to reduce the prevalence of sexual and gender-based violence and harmful practices, and increase women’s and girls’ access to sexual and reproductive health and rights, in accordance with the objectives of the Spotlight Initiative.

activity-description.narrative: The programme aims to reduce the prevalence of sexual and gender-based violence and harmful practices.

description.narrative:
Output 2.1 Key officials at national and/or sub-national levels in all relevant institutions are better able to develop and deliver evidence-based programmes that prevent and respond to VAWG, especially for those groups of women and girls facing intersecting and multiple forms of discrimination, including in other sectors
Output 2.2 Multi-stakeholder national and/or sub-national coordination mechanisms established at the highest level and/or strengthened that are adequately funded and include multi-sectoral representation and representation from the most marginalized groups
Output 4.1 Relevant government authorities and women’s rights organizations at national and sub-national levels have better knowledge and capacity to deliver quality and coordinated essential services, including SRH services and access to justice, to women and girls’ survivors of violence, especially those facing multiple and intersecting forms of discrimination
Output 6.1 Women's rights groups and relevant CSOs, have increased opportunities and support to share knowledge, network, partner and jointly advocate for GEWE and ending SGBV/HP, and promoting SRHR, with relevant stakeholders at sub-national, national, regional and global levels.

comment.narrative:
GOL Institution: One (1) MoGCSP CSO: 0
One (1) GBV Task force at National Level
46 WACPS Officer in 2017(28 males, 18 females)
1 Specialized Criminal Court (Court E) established in Montserrado County

2 CSOs and 1 national institution (Ministry of Justice) better able to develop and deliver evidence-based programmes to prevent and respond to VAWG
1 County assess and coordinating mechanism establish in Montserrado as well as national coordinating structures strengthen (1 GBV taskforce strengthen)
50 LNP/WACPS officers in Montserrado train and have specialized knowledge and capacity on SGBV/HP protection and prevention.
1 specialized Court E branch in Nimba establish and operational

1 CSO and 3 national security institutions: One National CSO recruited and enhanced the capacity of 6 local CSOs and 3 national security institutions (LNP, LDEA and MoND). CSOs and National security institutions developed and institutionalized costed action plans, conducted sensitization meeting in their areas of work, developed strategies among others. Additionally two consultants (national and international) have been hired and currently assessing the capacity need of national were hired to assess and enhance the capacity of government justice and security institutions to include the Ministry of Justice (Supreme Court, Liberia National Police, Liberia Drugs Enforcement Agency, Liberia Immigration Service, Bureau of Corrections and Rehabilitation), Ministry of National Defense, Armed Forces of Liberia, Liberia National Fire Service and few CSOs
5 county level multi-stakeholder coordination mechanism strengthened through the conduct of 2day capacity enhancement workshop with 167 participants (85 males and 82 females) from Nimba, Lofa, Montserrado, Grand Cape Mount and Grand Gedeh Counties in attendance representing criminal justice actors, gender officers, health workers and CSOs in each selected project county.
60 (comprises of 23 females and 37 males) LNP/WACPS investigators in the 5 selected project counties trained and have specialized knowledge and capacity on Sexual and Gender-based violence including harmful practices protection and prevention.

6 CSOs and 9 national institutions capacities strengthen to better develop and deliver evidence-based programmes to prevent and respond to VAWG
5 counties coordinating mechanism strengthen
50 LNP/WACPS officers in Montserrado capacity enhance and have specialized knowledge and capacity on SGBV/HP protection and prevention.
1 specialized Criminal Court E branch establish and operational in one county

A total of 181 (69 females and 122 males) criminal justice chain actors’ capacities were enhanced to strengthen response and accountability for SGBV, HP and SRHRs promotions. Criminal justice chain actors (prosecutors, magistrates, city solicitors, VSOs, CLOs, social workers, CSOs, HRs, traditional leaders, community leaders, LNP-WACPS officers, nurses, gender coordinators and etc.) working within the informal and formal justice sectors are being empowered to enhance accountability and human rights based approach in handling SGBV, HP and SRHRs violations in the five Spotlight counties.
As a result of the capacity needs assessment conducted in early 2020 to identify the capacity needs of nine (9) justice and security institutions(Liberia National Police (LNP), Bureau of Corrections (BCR), Drug Enforcement Agency (DEA), Liberia Immigrations Services(LIS), Liberia National Fire Service (LNFS), Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL), Ministry of National Defense (MoND), Ministry of Justice and Judiciary) in Montserrado, Lofa, Nimba, Grand Gedeh and Grand Cape Mount Counties, a one-day meeting was conducted with all Justices and Security institutions with the purpose to review and validate the assessment report.The assessment findings revealed a serious capacity gap in all of institutions that needs to be addressed in order to acquire the requisite knowledge and skills to provide adequate response, protection and prevention on SGBV, HTP and inculcate human rights-based approach into their daily work. Following the validation session, a four-day gender-mainstreaming training was conducted for targeted staff of the above mentioned institutions to provide the requisite knowledge and skills to those who are most likely to be first responders to sexual and gender-based violence cases to adequately respond to and address all forms of violence against women. With a total of 174 participants (88 females and 86 males) attending on selected days, the trainings sought to strengthen the capacity of security and justice institutions to respond to and eradicate cases of SGBV, harmful traditional practices (HTPs) and building better institutional frameworks for enhanced protection capacities and services to survivors. It furthered strengthened the institutions capacities to address all forms of violence against women and girls, and eliminate harmful practices, through a transformative and evidence-based approach. Furthermore, the training equipped the officers to address unequal power relations between men and women whilst focusing on gender equality and women’s empowerment in order to fulfil the principles of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. The training incorporated a human rights-based approach and took into consideration the specific needs of women and girls who experience multiple forms of violence and discrimination.
Four (4) national justice and security institutions (Liberia Immigration Service(LIS), Liberia Drugs Enforcement Agency (LDEA), Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) and Bureau of Corrections (BCR) in-service training curriculum were reviewed, revised and validated with the aim to mainstream gender, prevent and address SGBV with the integration of SGBV prevention, harmful practices prevention and SRHR promotion manuals.
51 (37 females and 14 males) LNP/WACPS officers in 5 Spotlight target counties capacity enhanced and have specialized knowledge to effectively investigate and charge to court SGBV Crimes and other violence against women and children.
Constructed two (2) new modern WACPS facilities at Zone 4 Base Police in Montserrado and Robertsport, Grand Cape Mount Counties and renovated two (2) WACPS offices in Mount Barclay Montserrado and in Tienii Grand Cape Mount Counties.
A total of two hundred seventy-one (271) survivors (all females) of sexual violence in Montserrado, Lofa, Nimba, Grand Gedeh and Grand Cape Mount counties were beneficiaries of support covering psychosocial counseling, feeding and transportation, emergency package, and medical assistance.
Supported 3 CSOs to conduct activities for awareness raising on prevention and awareness on COVID 19 and impact on women and girls especially with respect to violence at the household and community levels. CSOs provided PPE and WASH supplies to community leaders and women/youth groups. As a result of the interventions, the following were achieved: - Identified and supported ten (10) women groups/movements to carryout prevention awareness on COVID 19 and SGBV prevention including the Domestic Violence law. A total of 100 young women, girls and boys participated in the training sessions. - Supported rural women groups conducted 37 mobile community outreach activities on SGBV and COVID-19 preventive awareness in 50 project communities. These awareness activities reached a total of 16,666 people (Women: 4215, Men: 2685, Boys: 4234, Girls: 5532). As the result of these awareness initiatives, community dwellers have improved, and they reported in total 12 rape cases and facilitated the transportation of 10 of the rape perpetrators to criminal court E in Sanniquellie for trail. - 84 drive-through activities in twenty communities with at least two visits per community as jingo messages on stopping the spread of COVID-19/SGBV played on were held; - Procured and distributed 200 face shields, 100 packs of sanitary pads, 5000 pieces of locally produced face masks, 200 buckets branded with Spotlight logos and cartoons of detergents. - Monitored and reported SGBV cases involving physical violence, sexual violence and persistent nonsupport. During the period under review, a total of 111 cases were reported by CSOs covering Montserrado, Lofa, Nimba and Grand Cape Mount Counties. - 3 radio jingles were produced and are currently being aired on two local radio stations. Additionally, 16 editions of the radio programs are currently being processed for airing. The programs are aired once a week on Wednesdays. It focuses on SGBV with specific emphasis on the domestic violence law and COVID-19 pandemic.
Additionally, in December 2020, five (5) CSOs were awarded micro-grants to advocate and lobby for change in laws and policies at the same time create awareness on SGBV prevention in the five Spotlight Counties with interventions duration up until June 2021.

5 CSOs supported to lobby and advocate for change in laws and policies harmful to women and children
9 national justice and security institutions capacity enhanced to implement gender-sensitive HRM policies and the recommendations of the capacity needs assessment
National GBV taskforce and 5 counties level GBV taskforce supported
3 WACPS offices in Nimba, Lofa and Grand Gedeh renovated
1 specialized Criminal Court E branch establish and operational in one county
